ssshtest
 is designed to be practical and easy to use.


To use 
ssshtest
 in your project just source it in your test file


test -e ssshtest || wget -q https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ryanlayer/ssshtest/master/ssshtest
. ssshtest




Then write some tests:


run test_for_success python -c 
print 'zzz: example success'

assert_in_stdout 
zzz


run test_for_stderr python -c 
sys.stderr.write('zzz: example failure')

assert_in_stderr 
xxx





Then simply run the bash file that contains those lines.


$ bash mytests.sh




To run only certain tests, use:


base mytests.sh test_for_success test_42




Functions


run (2)


run a block of code. This must precede any of the testing functions below.

name for test.

assert_equal (2)

assert_equal 42 $((21 + 21))




assert_stdout (0)


Assert that stdout is not empty


run test_stdout python -c 
print 'zzz: example success'

assert_stdout




assert_in_stdout (1)


Assert that stdout out contains this text.


run test_in_stdout python -c 
print 'zzz: example success'

assert_in_stdout 
zzz

assert_no_stdout (0)


Assert that stdout is empty


run test_empty_stdout python -c

assert_no_stdout




assert_stderr (0)


Assert that stderr is not empty


run test_stderr python -c

assert_no_stderr




assert_exit_code (1)


Assert that the program exited with a particular code


Arguments




exit code




run test_exit_code python -c 
import sys; sys.exit(33)

assert_exit_code 33




Variables


STOP_ON_FAIL


Set STOP_ON_FAIL=1 after sourcing 
ssshtest
 to stop on the first error. Default is to continue running


STDOUT_FILE


$STDOUT_FILE
 is a file containing the $STDOUT from the last run command
